Typsetter signature, "Shaw," in pencil with bracket. Likely indicating a division of labor.
Not recorded in Bristow and Mitchell's transcription, The Nineteenth Century, and all future editions, printed the phrase "too often," rather than "too much."
In Intentions, Wilde removed the stage direction and replaced "All right." with "You will find me all attention."

Added "Besides, it is only the modern that ever becomes old-fashioned. M. Zola sits down to give us a picture of the Second Empire. Who cares for the Second Empire now? It is out of date. Life goes faster than Realism, but Romanticism is always in front of Life. " In Intentions

added "It follows, as a corollary from this, that external Nature also imitates Art. The only effects that she can show us are effects that we have already seen through poetry, or in paintings. This is the secret of Nature's charm, as well as the explanation of Nature's weakness." in Intentions
